GOD.content: literature as inheritance of promise of betrayal, w/ the forswearing [Kafka’s Letter to Father] that haunts this oath?
GOD.linkedContent: literature as inheritance of promise of betrayal, w/ the forswearing [Kafka’s Letter to Father] that haunts this oath?

MONL.content: declare under oath: “I have only one language and it is not mine”
MONL.linkedContent: declare under oath: “I have only one language and it is not mine”

R.content: fidelity to come, to the to-come, to the future, always trembling, risky, is held in friendship, friendship of thought: yes, there is friendship to (be) thought: oui, il y a de l’amitié à penser > we are guests to this snaking oath (serment) [D.H. Lawrence], in name of democracy
R.linkedContent: fidelity to come, to the to-come, to the future, always trembling, risky, is held in friendship, friendship of thought: yes, there is friendship to (be) thought: oui, il y a de l’amitié à penser > we are guests to this snaking oath (serment) [D.H. Lawrence], in name of democracy

FK.content: oath, sworn faith (foi jurée), pledge to God as witness: creates the unproducible, cannot not produce God as already there [déjà]
FK.linkedContent: oath, sworn faith (foi jurée), pledge to God as witness: creates the unproducible, cannot not produce God as already there [déjà]

FK.content: religio: promise, promises itself, already promised, the response to untranslatibility of religio is religio: to swear (Benveniste)
FK.linkedContent: religio: promise, promises itself, already promised, the response to untranslatibility of religio is religio: to swear (Benveniste)

H.content: Oedipus finds himself bound by an oath to which he is asymmetrically committed, committed before the god; when Theseus invokes the oath, everyone is hostage to the dead man
H.linkedContent: Oedipus finds himself bound by an oath to which he is asymmetrically committed, committed before the god; when Theseus invokes the oath, everyone is hostage to the dead man

H.content: from Oedipus at Colonus: oath (Orkos) hears everything

SPOM.content: “time is out of joint” at the moment there is an injunction to swear
SPOM.linkedContent: “time is out of joint” at the moment there is an injunction to swear

SPOM.content: the word conjuration produces a forever errant surplus value, by “capitalizing two orders of semantic value” [?]: 1) secret oath meant to silence 2) magical incantation used to evoke
SPOM.linkedContent: the word conjuration produces a forever errant surplus value, by “capitalizing two orders of semantic value” [?]: 1) secret oath meant to silence 2) magical incantation used to evoke

SPOM.content: via Marx, in Timon of Athens [see pp. 96-7 Marx’s play]: Timon’s trust in money (simulacrum, ghost), an oath, a giving credit, to that which is unworthy of oath; not convention society, or law > cult of money as nature, prostitution, thus constant perjury, simulacrum, greed
SPOM.linkedContent: via Marx, in Timon of Athens [see pp. 96-7 Marx’s play]: Timon’s trust in money (simulacrum, ghost), an oath, a giving credit, to that which is unworthy of oath; not convention society, or law > cult of money as nature, prostitution, thus constant perjury, simulacrum, greed

SPOM.content: privilege figure of conjuration (Verschwörung, Beschwörung) for another reason [not just fear]: swearing, taking an oath, committing oneself in performative, secret fashion
SPOM.linkedContent: privilege figure of conjuration (Verschwörung, Beschwörung) for another reason [not just fear]: swearing, taking an oath, committing oneself in performative, secret fashion

SPOM.content: [re: Eighteenth Brumaire: “conjure up spirits of past”] convoking (beschwören) spirits as specters, le geste d’une conjuration positive, celle qui jure pour appeler et non pour refouler
SPOM.linkedContent: [re: Eighteenth Brumaire: “conjure up spirits of past”] convoking (beschwören) spirits as specters, le geste d’une conjuration positive, celle qui jure pour appeler et non pour refouler

SPOM.content: jurer ou conjurer: the chance of thinking and its limit? the gift of its finitude? [nous gageons ici que la pensée ne vient jamais à bout de la pulsion conjuratoire]
SPOM.linkedContent: jurer ou conjurer: the chance of thinking and its limit? the gift of its finitude? [nous gageons ici que la pensée ne vient jamais à bout de la pulsion conjuratoire]

SPOM.content: Shakespeare was a great thinker and poet of the oath
SPOM.linkedContent: Shakespeare was a great thinker and poet of the oath

POOF.content: act of faith (reliability of oath) must belong to what is incalcuable in decision [a passivity beyond enérgeia, stability (bébaios) of act in Aristotle’s lover over beloved]: break w/ calculable is ordained by structure of confidence or of credence as faith
POOF.linkedContent: act of faith (reliability of oath) must belong to what is incalcuable in decision [a passivity beyond enérgeia, stability (bébaios) of act in Aristotle’s lover over beloved]: break w/ calculable is ordained by structure of confidence or of credence as faith

POOF.content: Aristotle’s bébaios [re: friendship] (temporal, becoming-intemporal, omnitemporal), stable & reliable, marks, covers over in marking, passage (through time) btwn 2 heterogenous orders: 1) assured calculable reliability 2) act of faith [unyoked there’s difference]
POOF.linkedContent: Aristotle’s bébaios [re: friendship] (temporal, becoming-intemporal, omnitemporal), stable & reliable, marks, covers over in marking, passage (through time) btwn 2 heterogenous orders: 1) assured calculable reliability 2) act of faith [unyoked there’s difference]

POOF.content: in Menexenus, must summon dead to be responsible before them, the dead are made to be born again: oath of this co-engagement thus resembles a fraternal conjuration
POOF.linkedContent: in Menexenus, must summon dead to be responsible before them, the dead are made to be born again: oath of this co-engagement thus resembles a fraternal conjuration

POOF.content: Benveniste’s etymology of phílos, its relation to home, hospitality & oath, but in Homer phílos has vague possessive quality (‘his knees,’ ‘his son’)
POOF.linkedContent: Benveniste’s etymology of phílos, its relation to home, hospitality & oath, but in Homer phílos has vague possessive quality (‘his knees,’ ‘his son’)

POOF.content: necessity in Menexenus, everything decided where decision does not take place, where always-already taken place: at birth, day before birth, eugenic/noble birth > this makes noble, makes political, ties phúsis to nómos, ontology to oath (ties what is to what must be), obligatory process of a natural law: a synthetic a priori necessity
POOF.linkedContent: necessity in Menexenus, everything decided where decision does not take place, where always-already taken place: at birth, day before birth, eugenic/noble birth > this makes noble, makes political, ties phúsis to nómos, ontology to oath (ties what is to what must be), obligatory process of a natural law: a synthetic a priori necessity

POOF.content: as long as brothers remain faithful to memory of their fathers (specters of their fathers of noble birth), they are bound by testamentary tie (recalls their truth, truth qua political truth), a monumental memory that inaugurates truth as much as it recalls it
POOF.linkedContent: as long as brothers remain faithful to memory of their fathers (specters of their fathers of noble birth), they are bound by testamentary tie (recalls their truth, truth qua political truth), a monumental memory that inaugurates truth as much as it recalls it

POOF.content: [Derrida speaking to himself in parentheses] is one every born a brother? isn’t there always an oath? a memory? the brother is always a foster brother? would the sister than be a case of fraternity? [Schwurbrüderschaft]
POOF.linkedContent: [Derrida speaking to himself in parentheses] is one every born a brother? isn’t there always an oath? a memory? the brother is always a foster brother? would the sister than be a case of fraternity? [Schwurbrüderschaft]

FWT.content: heritage of circumcision precedes speech, oath, contract

SW.content: [to read the corpus that has known, from operation of other, how to undo itself from veiling/unveiling] you have to write, sign in turn, countersign in writing, something else, in another language, w/out betraying injection/call of first seal
SW.linkedContent: [to read the corpus that has known, from operation of other, how to undo itself from veiling/unveiling] you have to write, sign in turn, countersign in writing, something else, in another language, w/out betraying injection/call of first seal

SW.content: can’t prove it happened, only swear that it did: perjury must remain possible (a duty that must be respected)
SW.linkedContent: can’t prove it happened, only swear that it did: perjury must remain possible (a duty that must be respected)

DPi.content: for Nietzsche, at all solemn festivals, there comes back (nachwirkt) a remainder of fear that presided over all acts of memory, promises, oaths, engagements
DPi.linkedContent: for Nietzsche, at all solemn festivals, there comes back (nachwirkt) a remainder of fear that presided over all acts of memory, promises, oaths, engagements

DPi.content: secret: what if I deconstructed the “seminar” by telling you I won’t tell you the truth even if I know it? > blow to deconstructed pieces the idea of the seminar that’s obliged by oath to speak all possible truth
DPi.linkedContent: secret: what if I deconstructed the “seminar” by telling you I won’t tell you the truth even if I know it? > blow to deconstructed pieces the idea of the seminar that’s obliged by oath to speak all possible truth

HLP.content: lying as making him believe [dimension of credit/faith irreducible], bad faith of liar, betrayal of implicit sworn faith, surprising the good faith of his addressee
HLP.linkedContent: lying as making him believe [dimension of credit/faith irreducible], bad faith of liar, betrayal of implicit sworn faith, surprising the good faith of his addressee

TR.content: swearing, oaths, acts of faith: jurer, conjurer, abjurer > these events ought to [from MOP perspective] resist mechanization, but don’t
TR.linkedContent: swearing, oaths, acts of faith: jurer, conjurer, abjurer > these events ought to [from MOP perspective] resist mechanization, but don’t

TR.content: in the beginning, there will have been the act & the word: the act of swearing
TR.linkedContent: in the beginning, there will have been the act & the word: the act of swearing

TR.content: [re: “to swear”] délire names extraordinary coincidence of irrationality of machine (beyond my control) & absolute sincerity (authentic innocence of my intentions)
TR.linkedContent: [re: “to swear”] délire names extraordinary coincidence of irrationality of machine (beyond my control) & absolute sincerity (authentic innocence of my intentions)

TR.content: coincidence of infinite guilt & certainty in absolute, virgin, intact innocence> btwn infinite guilt & absence of guilty conscience
TR.linkedContent: coincidence of infinite guilt & certainty in absolute, virgin, intact innocence> btwn infinite guilt & absence of guilty conscience

TR.content: protest of accusatory innocence: forgive me this my virtue [ask forgiveness for feeling innocent]
TR.linkedContent: protest of accusatory innocence: forgive me this my virtue [ask forgiveness for feeling innocent]

TR.content: Rousseau abjures Protestantism (freer, more intentionalist, more spiritual), he converts mechanically to more mechanical, ritualistic Catholicism
TR.linkedContent: Rousseau abjures Protestantism (freer, more intentionalist, more spiritual), he converts mechanically to more mechanical, ritualistic Catholicism

TR.content: confession: 1) confession of sin 2) profession of faith (oath)
TR.linkedContent: confession: 1) confession of sin 2) profession of faith (oath)

TR.content: oath not to betray, more important than truth to be revealed (beginning of Rousseau’s Confessions)
TR.linkedContent: oath not to betray, more important than truth to be revealed (beginning of Rousseau’s Confessions)

PJP.content: every lie is a perjury, every perjury implies a lie, betrays a promise or implicit oath (“I owe you the truth”)
PJP.linkedContent: every lie is a perjury, every perjury implies a lie, betrays a promise or implicit oath (“I owe you the truth”)

PJP.content: d’avoir perjuré en jurant: 2 moments of perjury envelop each other; was the promise not to lie, the swearing, truthful?
PJP.linkedContent: d’avoir perjuré en jurant: 2 moments of perjury envelop each other; was the promise not to lie, the swearing, truthful?

PJP.content: the 2 moments are rigorously distinct & strangely indiscernible: difference of times inscribed under law, contract, this law is the Law itself (annuls the difference, sublates into fidelity of oath)
PJP.linkedContent: the 2 moments are rigorously distinct & strangely indiscernible: difference of times inscribed under law, contract, this law is the Law itself (annuls the difference, sublates into fidelity of oath)

PJP.content: structural signification of oath, Law itself, origin of Law: commit to not be affected by time
PJP.linkedContent: structural signification of oath, Law itself, origin of Law: commit to not be affected by time

PJP.content: but the perjurer can always plead the discontinuity of time
PJP.linkedContent: but the perjurer can always plead the discontinuity of time

PJP.content: oath, sworn faith, and the Law force psycho-phenomenology of self to lie [not 2 sequential moments, but perjured in advance]; which is madder: psyche, logos, ego—or the oath?
PJP.linkedContent: oath, sworn faith, and the Law force psycho-phenomenology of self to lie [not 2 sequential moments, but perjured in advance]; which is madder: psyche, logos, ego—or the oath?

EL.content: God’s voice sealed, on reserve in sacred language, like a signature, the oath of the covenant or faith tying us to God: content of this hidden speech will take form again, meaning will take on form in manifestation, to hear & to say will renew the covenant
EL.linkedContent: God’s voice sealed, on reserve in sacred language, like a signature, the oath of the covenant or faith tying us to God: content of this hidden speech will take form again, meaning will take on form in manifestation, to hear & to say will renew the covenant

EL.content: sacred language: “con-juration" itself (conjuration btwn God & us)

LI.content: Derrida swears his good faith (raises his hand above the typewriter)

AD.content: violence of pure face to face (hospitable welcome, narcissistic closing [renfermement]): in double bind w/ the 3rd (protects against vertigo of ethical violence while violating its purity)
AD.linkedContent: violence of pure face to face (hospitable welcome, narcissistic closing [renfermement]): in double bind w/ the 3rd (protects against vertigo of ethical violence while violating its purity)

AD.content: pure face to face as oath (serment) before the letter, debt before every contract or loan (emprunt), must perjure itself in bind w/ 3rd: in operation of justice can no longer distinguish btwn fidelity of oath & perjury of false witness
AD.linkedContent: pure face to face as oath (serment) before the letter, debt before every contract or loan (emprunt), must perjure itself in bind w/ 3rd: in operation of justice can no longer distinguish btwn fidelity of oath & perjury of false witness

AD.content: justice as law begins w/ perjury > violates; sigh of just man: “Qu’ai-je à faire avec la justice?”
AD.linkedContent: justice as law begins w/ perjury > violates; sigh of just man: “Qu’ai-je à faire avec la justice?”

BSi.content: oath of brothers after founding criminality [killing baby daddy], trace of primitive crime remains ineffaceable in egalitarian, compassional, communitarian fraternity
BSi.linkedContent: oath of brothers after founding criminality [killing baby daddy], trace of primitive crime remains ineffaceable in egalitarian, compassional, communitarian fraternity

BSi.content: if I swear that I know what I mean when I injure someone [w/ bêtise], I perjure myself > bêtise always perspectival
BSi.linkedContent: if I swear that I know what I mean when I injure someone [w/ bêtise], I perjure myself > bêtise always perspectival

OG.content: Rousseau: cradle of nations, first fires of love born at water wells; p. 267 “well of oath” in Genesis XXI
OG.linkedContent: Rousseau: cradle of nations, first fires of love born at water wells; p. 267 “well of oath” in Genesis XXI

UWC.content: what we call “professions” tend to be nonmercenary arts, imply testimonial commitment, responsibility under oath (freely declared): physician, lawyer, professor
UWC.linkedContent: what we call “professions” tend to be nonmercenary arts, imply testimonial commitment, responsibility under oath (freely declared): physician, lawyer, professor
